column4: I reckon ubuntu talks softly to usb devices convincing them to mount like magic?
what is the problem you are having with your removable device?
I'm a curious type. I wanted to configure whatever is automagically mounting usb devices to try to configure the default permissions for vfat devices
this is linux after all, should be easy to custom simple file permissions, isn't it?
how curious are you? there are graphical ways to control automounts
including default permissions? I'm quite curious actually ;-)
do you want to assign permissions to the entire drive?
yes.
namely devices that don't have file permissions understandable by linux (eg. FAT32)
So that normal users can read what's on the thumb drives, but can't write to it
you should be able to change /etc/fstab to make the device write-able
right, but then every new device would get a random "/dev/sd?" file for it
it's kludgy to use the fstab, there should be a daemon doing the automounting, don't you think?
and it should have some kind of documentation, but it seems something so simple is so hard to find
true, i get what you're after now, but i'm not aware of how to do that
thanks. Any idea where I can find decent documentation on the subject?
i don't know where to look.  there is a program in the repos called Mount Manager, but I haven't done anything with it (sounds like a graphical tool for /etc/fstab)
thanks for finding this. How it auto mounts USB devices continues a mistery though, eh?
as far as i can tell, yes
oh well, bugger. Thank you so much for spending time on my question. It was really appreciated.
good luck

In case you are still interested, it seems that "gnome-volume-manager" handles the auto-mounting of devices on Ubuntu. Why, oh, why rely on a Gnome tool to handle mounting is beyond my ability to comprehend ;-)
it seems to rely on HAL (seems like a kludge to detect changes to the system) to know what to mount
cool, thanks
